| region1 = <!-- first region (country)'s name --> Saudi Arabia | pop1 = <!-- population in first region --> 28,000 Bedouins (1960s)<ref>Bedouin Ethnobotany: Plant Concepts and Uses in a Desert Pastoral World page 50</ref> (Not including settled population) | ref1 = <!-- <ref>erence/s supporting pop1 data --> | region2 = | pop2 = | ref2 = | region3 = | pop3 = | ref3 = <!-- etc, to: --> | region33 = | pop33 = | ref33 =
| languages = southern [[Najdi Arabic|Najdi dialect]]<ref name="ReferenceA">Bedouin Ethnobotany: Plant Concepts and Uses in a Desert Pastoral World</ref> | religions = [[Sunni Islam]] ([[Hanbali]]) | related_groups = [[Al Murrah]], [[Al-Hawajir|Bani Hajer]], [[Banu Yam|Yam]], [[Ajman]] | footnotes = }}
'''Qahtān''' ({{Lang-ar|قحطان}}, also spelled as {{Lang|ar|القحطاني}}) to distinguish between the tribe and the Qahtanite peoples, is an [[Arab]] tribal confederation. Qahtan is composed of three main tribes: Sanhan, Junb, and Rufaida. Today, members of the tribe and its sub-tribes are based in [[Saudi Arabia]] (where most of the tribe is congregated), [[Kuwait]], [[Qatar]], and the [[United Arab Emirates]]. One must note that the [[Madh'hij]]i Qahtan tribe is different from the [[Qahtanite]] peoples, because while all members of the Qahtan identify as Qahtanite through their ancestry to Qahtan son of [[Hud (prophet)|Hud]] which the tribe is named after, not all Qahtanite tribes (such as Shammar, Sharhan, Harb, etc.) trace their ancestry back to the modern tribe known as ''Qahtan''.
Qahtan's sheikhdom was unanimously agreed by Western historians to be in the hands of the 'Al Qarmalah' family of the Jahader clan in the 19th century, and as early as 1961, the paramount sheikh of Qahtan was reported to be 'Khalil ibn Nasir ibn Qarmalah' (a descendant of Hadi ibn Qarmalah).<ref name="ReferenceA"/> However today, this subject of whether the Al Qarmalah family or the Ibn Dulaim family of the Sharif clan are the rightful sheikhs of Qahtan is highly controversial and has led to physical confrontations in high profile tribal Qahtan congregations. Regardless, Abdullah ibn Fahad ibn Dulaim, sheikh of the Ibn Dulaim family, is recognized by the Saudi state as the appointed paramount sheikh of Qahtan and its allied tribe of Wadi'a.<ref>https://arabi21.com/story/1050599/%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%AA%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B9-%D9%82%D8%AD%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%8A%D8%B3%D8%A8%D8%A8-%D8%AE%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%86-%D8%A3%D8%A8%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%84%D8%A9-%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%AF</ref>
==History== ===Rule of Al Qarmalah=== The Qahtan tribe enjoyed priority rights and control to southern Najd for a period generally agreed to have spanned 90 years, paying suzerainty only to Ibn Saud. Tribes who migrated to Najd during spring or winter to herd their cattle were required to pay taxation in order for them to be allowed to graze their livestock in the Qahtani diyar (territory) in Najd.<ref name="auto">^ جامعة الملك سعود / قسم التاريخ - كلية الاداب</ref> Several historians have described Qahtan as "the most powerful" tribe or "nobody dared to challenge them" during this era.<ref>Alexei Vassiliev The History of Saudi Arabia</ref>
The ''Jahader'' branch of the Sanhan sub-tribe of Qahtan migrated to southern Najd from their homelands in Asir Region during the late 18th century and early 19th century under the leadership of Athfar al-Amaaj, driving out the Mutair tribe from Najd after refusing to pay taxation to Mutair in exercising their rights to herding camels and cattle in Najd.<ref>المصدر : كتاب تاريخ نجد – لابن غنام – صفحة 82</ref> After Qahtan's victory over Mutair, a previously unknown member of the Jahader known as Hadi ibn Qurmula visited Ibn Saud whom he convinced to grant him the sheikhdom of Qahtan. This began the 90 year rule of Al Qurmula over Najd, beginning with Hadi ibn Qurmula and culminating with his son Muhammad ibn Hadi ibn Qurmula.<ref>ج.ج لويمر ج 1 ص 499-500.</ref> .<ref name="auto"/>
===Migration of Bani Hajer===
==Branches== The Qahtan tribe is subdivided into three major branches: Sanhan سنحان, Junb جنب and Rufaida رفيدة each major branch is divided into many clans, each clan is divided into various families.
*'''Sanhan''' The Sanhan tribe are as follows: ** al-Habab ** al-Jahader ** Al al-Sari ** Al Umar *'''Junb''' The Junb tribe are as follows: ** [[Al-Hawajir|Bani Hajer (al-Hajri)]] ** Sharif ** Bani Beshr ** Obaida (al-Obaidi) *'''Rufaida'''
===Iraq=== Most Qahtanite tribes in Iraq (such as Shemmar, Dulaim, Juboor, etc.) do not belong to the [[Madh'hij]]i tribe of Qahtan. However, few tribes belonging to the aforementioned [[Madh'hij]]i tribe of Qahtan are present in Iraq, a prominent example being the Kobaisat tribal confederation. The Kobaisat (al-Kobaisi) migrated from Tathlith, modern southern Saudi Arabia in the 16th century and settled in Iraq. By the 18th century, many of the Kobaisat migrated to the growing pearl towns of northern Qatar and are a prominent tribe today in that country. The Kobaisat today in Iraq are a large tribal confederation that was also joined by non-Kobaisat tribes such as al-Buhaidar and al-Durai'at, and have formed their own town known as ''Kobaisa''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alshawaf.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=50&Itemid=58|title=قبيلة الكبيسات|first=|last=Administrator|website=www.alshawaf.net}}</ref> It must be noted that the Kobaisat are entirely independent from Qahtan and the only aspect linking the two tribes together today is ancestry. Some well known members of the Kobaisat tribe are Iraqi religious scholar [[Mohammed Alkobaisi]] and Ahmed al-Kobaisi, the latter whom is most famous for participating in anti-Salafist debate shows.
===Kuwait=== In Kuwait, Qahtan and its sub-tribe [[Al-Hawajir|Bani Hajir]] have formed a well known alliance in National Assembly elections, being a part of the tribal bloc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/ar/article/local/2009/04/20/113146/nr/nc|title=طلال السهلي: الالتزام في العهد وميثاق التحالف مع الهواجر وبني قحطان والعتبان والمطران|publisher=}}</ref> The Bani Hajir are among the largest tribal blocs to participate in the Kuwait National Assembly elections, consisting of 8150 voters in the 2016 election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alqabas.com/67101/|title=بالفيديو – قراءة في السجل الانتخابي للدائرة الخامسة: لأول مرة الرجال أكثر عدداً من النساء - القبس الإلكتروني|publisher=}}</ref>
===Qatar=== Qahtan, specifically the Bani Hajer tribe, has taken a very prominent role in the Qatar peninsula ever since their migration to that country in the 18th century. The Bani Hajers were infamous in the 19th century for their nomadic lifestyle, political and tribal alliances, and piratical activities in the Persian Gulf.<ref>دليل الخليج. الجزء الأول. المواد التاريخية والسياسية.</ref> In fact, the vast majority of Bani Hajer inhabited the Qatar peninsula until around 1900 when most of the tribe migrated west to modern day Saudi Arabia in Al-Ahsa and Jubail after a dispute with the ruling Qatari [[Al Thani]] family. As a result of their loyalty and military service to [[Al Saud]], in the Eastern region of Saudi Arabia, the Bani Hajers were awarded settlement rights in an area known today as "Jawf Bani Hajer", and there they also established several [[hijras]].<ref>Bedouin Ethnobotany: Plant Concepts and Uses in a Desert Pastoral World page 48 and 49</ref> Branches of Qahtan such as al-Habab (known as al-Ehbabi in Qatar) also have a presence in that country but their fame is not nearly as recognized as that of Bani Hajer. Perhaps the most recognized Hajri personality in Qatar would be Mozah Al Mesned, the mother of the current Emir of Qatar [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]], who belongs to the Al Muhannada branch of the Bani Hajer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marefa.org/%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B5%D8%B1_%D8%A8%D9%86_%D8%B9%D8%A8%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%86%D8%AF|title=ناصر بن عبد الله المسند - المعرفة|website=www.marefa.org}}</ref>
===Bahrain=== Bahrain is a Gulf country that houses the tiniest number of Qahtanis compared to other Gulf countries, however, some members of the tribe have taken a relatively prominent role in the country. For example, the head of the Sunni Waqf Endowment Directorate is Rashid al-Hajri, a member of the Bani Hajer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alayam.com/online/local/549725/News.html|title=صدور أمر ملكي بتعيين الشيخ راشد الهاجري رئيساً لمجلس الأوقاف السنية|publisher=}}</ref> Offshoot Hajri families such Almuhannada also take a public role such as former Member of Parliament Hamad Almuhannadi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/news/497331.html|title=الكتل النيابية تحت قبة البرلمان|publisher=}}</ref>
===United Arab Emirates=== Qahtan takes a noteworthy role in the United Arab Emirates, which however is not as large as Kuwait or Qatar. For example, a member of the Advisory Council to the Government of [[Sharjah]] is Abdulqader al-Hajri, a member of Bani Hajer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://emarati.katib.org/2011/03/09/%d8%a5%d9%85%d8%a7%d8%b1%d8%a7%d8%aa%d9%8a%d9%88%d9%86-%d9%8a%d8%b1%d9%81%d8%b9%d9%88%d9%86-%d8%b1%d8%b3%d8%a7%d9%84%d8%a9-%d9%84%d8%ad%d9%83%d8%a7%d9%85-%d8%a7%d9%84%d8%a5%d9%85%d8%a7%d8%b1%d8%a7/|title=إماراتيون يرفعون رسالة لحكام الإمارات تطالب بإصلاح كلي للنظام البرلماني : مواطن إماراتي مغلوب على أمره|publisher=}}</ref> The Bani Hajer were also historically allied with the al-Manasir tribe, which sometimes may claim descent from Bani Hajer based on their historical alliance.<ref name="ReferenceA">Bedouin Ethnobotany: Plant Concepts and Uses in a Desert Pastoral World</ref> Smaller families of Qahtan such as "al-Ehbabi" are also present in the country.
==Notable members== * [[Saud al-Qahtani]], former Advisor of the Saudi Royal court and the former General Supervisor of the Center for Studies and Information Affairs at minister rank. <ref>https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/gulf/2017/07/06/Saudi-official-23-thousand-account-recruited-by-Qatar-to-attack-Saudi-Arabia.html</ref> * [[Grand Mosque seizure|Muhammad al-Qahtani]], Saudi Arabian millennial Salafist anti-government rebel and spiritual leader ("Mahdi") of the 1979 [[Grand Mosque Seizure|seizure]] of the Grand Mosque of Mecca. * [[Mohammed al-Qahtani|Mohammed Mana al-Qahtani]], Saudi Arabian terrorist held in extrajudicial detention at [[Guantanamo Bay]] * [[Yasser Al-Qahtani|Yasser al-Qahtani]], Saudi Arabian footballer * [[Haji Bakr Al-Qahtani]], Saudi Arabian sprinter * [[Mesfer Al-Qahtani]], Saudi Arabian sprinter * [[Abdulkareem Al-Qahtani]], Saudi Arabian footballer * [[Ali Al-Hajri]], Kuwaiti member of the [[National Assembly (Kuwait)|National Assembly]] * [[Ali Bin Fahad Al-Hajri]], Qatari ambassador to the United States * [[Nasser Al Hajri]], retired Kuwaiti football player * [[Saud Al Hajiri]], Qatari football player * [[Saeed Al-Hajri (bowler)|Saeed al-Hajri]], Qatari bowler

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:Sebastao Rodolfo Dalgado.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Sebastião Rodolfo Dalgado]] '''[[Msgr]] Sebastião Rodolfo Dalgado''' ([[Konkani]] [[devnagri script]]: सॆबास्तियाँव रॊदॊल्फ़ो दाल्गादॊ; [[Konkani]] '[[romi script]]' : Sebastiaom Rodolf Dalgad; 8 May 1855 – 4 April 1922) was an [[Indian people|Indo]]-[[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] [[Catholic]] priest, academic, university professor, theologian, [[Orientalism|orientalist]] and [[Linguistics|linguist]].
Dalgado distinguished himself as a linguist and etymologist in the study of the influences of the Portuguese language on a number of languages of [[Southeast Asia]]. He was a corresponding member of the [[Lisbon Academy of Sciences]], elected on July 27, 1911.He also became widely renowned during his lifetime as a [[Konkani]] language [[scholar]].
==Early life== Sebastião Rodolfo Dalgado, was born in [[Assagao]], [[Bardez]], Goa,<ref>{{Harvnb|Pereira|1983|p=7}}</ref> to a [[Goan Catholic]] family of the [[Roman Catholic Brahmin|Bamonn]] caste.<ref name="Dalgado"/> He had six brothers and a sister. The family's pre-conversion surname was Desai, replaced by the [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] surname [[Dalgado]], after conversion to Christianity.<ref name="Dalgado">{{harvnb|Dalgado|Soares|1988|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3qk-p5hKuccC&pg=PR12 57]}}</ref>
The second son of Ambrose Dalgado, a landowner in Bardez, and Florinda Rosa de Souza, he had six brothers and one sister. Among the siblings were [[Daniel Gelásio Dalgado]], a medical director of the health services from [[Sawantwadi]] and an eminent botanist; Patrocínio Dalgado, ophthalmologist; and Eduardo Dalgado, a lawyer in Lisbon.
==Career== After completing his elementary studies in [[Assagao]], the young Dalgado completed his secondary education in [[Mapusa]] and joined the [[Rachol Seminary]], near [[Margao]], from where he was ordained a priest in 1881.
Considered the best student of his course, he was selected for further studies and then went on to Rome, where he enrolled at the [[Seminary of St. Apollinaris]].
In Rome his doctorate was in [[Canon Law]] and [[Roman Law]].
==Return from Lisbon==
After a brief stay in Lisbon in 1884, he returned to Goa as a missionary, where the then [[Patriarch of the East Indies]], Don [[António Sebastião Valente]], appointed him as the inspector of schools and workshops of the [[Padroado do Oriente]] and as a professor of Scripture and Canon Law at the [[Seminary of Rachol]], where he formerly studied. He also functioned as an ecclesiastical judge in Goa.
Subsequently, he was intensely involved in religious activity in India, and then became [[vicar general]] of the [[island of Ceylon]], particularly of the Portuguese mission in the city of [[Colombo]], which had been abolished by [[Concordat of 1886]].
Later, he served at [[Calcutta]], where he founded a school for girls and a dispensary for the poor in [[Nagori]], and [[Dhaka]].
==Close contacts with languages==
All this activity enabled him to forge close contacts with various language communities, thus allowing him to acquire a mastery of several Indian languages, including [[Malayalam]], [[Kannada]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Sinhalese language|Sinhala]] and [[Bengali language|Bengali]]. Learning some of these languages was made easier due to his deep knowledge of [[Sanskrit]].
Between 1893 and 1895 he was vicar-general in [[Honnavar]], today in the State of Karnataka. There he served a community of Konkani and Kannada speakers, the latter being a language he learnt. It took some time in [[Sawantwadi]], with his brother Gelasius Dalgado, who was a doctor there, for him to learn other dialects of Konkani.
When he was vicar general of [[Ceylon]], he declined to accept the bishop's mitre that the [[Congregation of Propaganda Fide]] had offered him, probably in the context of the dispute between Portugal and the [[Holy See]] on the extent and powers of the [[Patronage of the East]] ([[Padroado]]).
During his stay in [[Ceylon]], he wrote several sermons and homilies in the Indo-Portuguese dialect of Ceylon. His other work included ''[[The Indo-Portuguese Dialect of Ceylon]],'' published in 1900 in ''Contributions of the Geographical Society of Lisbon'', done in commemoration of the centenary of the European discovery of sea route to India.
==Dictionaries==
His first published work was the first part of ''Konkani-Portuguese Dictionary'', written using the [[Devanagari]] alphabet and the Roman script, and which was published in 1893 in the city of Bombay, now known as [[Mumbai]].
In 1895 he settled in [[Lisbon]], where he completed the publication of the ''Konkani-Portuguese Dictionary'' (which was out in 1905) and devoted himself to study the influence of [[English language|English]] on the languages of the [[Indian subcontinent]].
In view of its studies published, in 1907 he was appointed Professor of Sanskrit in the [[Curso Superior de Letras]], which was founded in 1859 by D. [[Pedro V]] in [[Lisbon]]. This institution later on went on to become the nucleus of the Faculty of Arts of the [[University of Lisbon]].
==Recognition==
In 1911 he was elected corresponding member of the [[Academy of Sciences]], and received the title of ''Doutor em Letras'', which was granted by the Council of the Faculty of Arts of Lisbon (''Conselho da Faculdade de Letras de Lisboa'').
He suffered from [[diabetes]], which ultimately resulted in the amputation of both his legs (in 1911 and 1915.) From that point onwards, Dalgado used a wheelchair.
Because of his handicap, the Faculty of Humanities granted him the privilege of performing his duties from his home, where his students gathered around him to hear his lessons. He also undertook the daily celebration of Mass in his wheelchair, with special religious permission.
When he died, on 4 April 1922, his funeral rites reflected the wide prestige that had won. In attendance were the Patriarch of Lisbon, the Apostolic Nuncio in Lisbon, the Minister of Education and representatives of colleges and academies of Lisbon.
The funeral eulogy was delivered by Canon [[José de Santa Rita e Sousa]], professor of the ''Escola Superior Colonial'', where he taught the chair of Konkani language. The press coverage was large, reflecting throughout the Lusophone world.
He was an eminent [[philologist]], publishing, among other works, the ''Glossário Luso-Asiático'' in two volumes, full-text versions of which are available online today. He was also the author of outstanding works in the field of Portuguese [[Orientalism]] such as ''The Indo-Portuguese dialect of Ceylon''; ''Konkani-Portuguese Dictionary''; ''The Indo-Portuguese dialect of Mumbai and suburbs''; ''Influencia do vocabulário português em línguas asiáticas'' (The Influence of Portuguese Vocables in Asian Languages); ''The Indo-Portuguese Dialects of Goa, Daman and Ceylon''; ''Fundamentals of the Sanskrit language'', and ''Indian Proverbs''.
His works have earned high praise, including that of Dr. [[Aniceto dos Reis Gonçalves Viana|Gonçalves Viana]] who appreciated his work ''The Influence of Portuguese Vocables in Asian Languages'' and said ''that perhaps no other wise person, Portuguese or foreign, could carry it out satisfactorily''.
The Brazilian philologist Dr. [[Solidonio Leite]] said that "Monsignor Dalgado could undertake and carry out those works that attest to exceptional value of this great man".<ref>[http://www.supergoa.com/pt/read/news_cronica.asp?c_news=286 Monsignor Rodolfo Dalgado (1855–1922)] {{pt icon}}</ref>
In recognition of his work in 1904, he received the honour of honorary chaplain of the Pope's ''extra urbem'', with the right to use the title of "[[Monsignor]]". He was a member of the [[Lisbon Geographic Society]] (1895), a member of the [[Institute of Coimbra]] (1896), Doctor ''Honoris Causa'' from the Faculty of Arts, University of Lisbon (1911), corresponding member Academy of Sciences (1911) and its member (1922) and a member of the [[Royal Asiatic Society]] in [[London]] (1921).
In 1922, the [[Academy of Sciences of Lisbon]], which bequeathed the 300 documents that constitute the Monsignor Dalgado Fund, admitted him posthumously as a member. Along with [[Shenoi Goembab]] and [[Joaquim Heliodoró da Cunha Rivara]], Sebastião Rodolfo Dalgado is widely considered to be a pioneer in the defence of the [[Konkani]] language.
The city of Lisbon honoured him with a place named after him, to a wide locality in the parish of [[São Domingos de Benfica]]. In 1955 the ''Correios do Estado da Índia'' (postal department of the Estado da Índia) issued a postage stamp of a one real denomination, to mark the centenary of the birth of Monsignor Sebastiao Rodolfo Delgado, accompanied by a postcard with his photograph.
In 1989, the [[Goan]] state capital of [[Panjim]] saw the creation of the [[Dalgado Konkani Academy]], an academy to promote the use of the [[Konkani language]] in the Latin alphabet (the [[Konkani in the Roman script|''Konkani Romi lipi'']]). The [[Dalgado Konkani Academy]] has also established the Monsignor Sebastiao Rudolfo Dalgado Award to be awarded annually for activities to promote the study and use of Konkani.<ref>[http://www.mail-archive.com/goanet@goanet.org/msg25931.html Msgr Sebastiao Rodolfo Dalgado Award 2005].</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Sophia Namutebi | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1979}} | birth_place = [[Uganda]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = |occupation = Businesswoman, [[entrepreneur]], [[traditional healer]] and community leader | years_active = Since 1995 | nationality = Ugandan | ethnicity = | citizenship = Uganda | residence = [[Kampala]], Uganda | known_for = Business | networth = | home_town = Kampala | title = | spouse = |religion = }}
'''Sophia Namutebi''', also known as '''Sofia Namutebi''', '''Sylvia Namutebi''', and '''Maama Fiina''', is a [[Uganda]]n businesswoman, [[traditional healer]], and community leader. She was listed in 2013 as one of the wealthiest people in Uganda.<ref name="Wel">{{cite web | title=Some of Uganda's richest women | newspaper=[[New Vision (newspaper)|New Vision]] | date=3 March 2013 | first=Maureen | last=Nakatudde | url=https://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1314989/ugandas-richest-women | accessdate=16 November 2017 | location=Kampala}}</ref>
==Background== Namutebi was born in [[Mukono District]] circa 1979<ref name="Beg"/> in a family with modest means. She dropped out of school at an early age and while still a teenager, gave birth to her daughter Safina (abbreviated as Fiina). She worked as a maid to support herself and her daughter. When she was 16 years old, she relocated to Kampala, the country's capital city, where she began hawking merchandise on the streets.<ref name="Beg">{{cite web | accessdate=16 November 2017 | location=Kampala | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Business/Commodities/Maama-Fiina--the-business-empress/688610-2141834-ba6piu/index.html | title=Maama Fiina, the business empress | date=11 January 2014 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | first=Edgar | last=Batte}}</ref>
In 1995, she borrowed UGX:38,000 and bought a consignment of polythene bags to hawk on the streets. She grew her capital to UGX:3 million in a short time. She bought a commuter taxi (matatu or kamunye), recycling the profits into a second vehicle and a third one, over time.<ref name="Beg"/>
In 1998, she began importing cloth from [[Dubai]] to make the women's attire called [[gomesi]] or [[busuuti]], worn in Uganda. Namutebi recalls that in 1999, she had four commuter taxis plying the [[Kampala–Jinja Highway]], each valued at UGX:8.5 million, representing almost 1,000 fold what she had borrowed in 1995.<ref name="Beg"/>
==Her businesses== With the commuter taxis and the gomesi business continuing to bring in income, she diversified into the motorcycles taxi business. She would buy a motorcycle at UGX:720,000 each and lease to a rider-operator with payments totaling UGX:1,400,000 by the end of the lease-purchase. Starting with 20 motorcycles, her business grew to 500 vehicles.<ref name="Beg"/>
Her other investments include garment shops in downtown Kampala, [[Masaka]], and [[Mityana]]. She owns secondary schools in [[Mukono Town|Mukono]] and Mityana.<ref name="Wel"/> She has real estate investments in residential and commercial property in various locations in the country. She is also involved in the importation of used cars from Japan for sale to retail customers. Maama Fiina says she does not earn much from her business as a traditional healer.<ref name="Beg"/>
==Family== In September 2017, Namutebi was married to Ismail Ssegujja, a businessman. The wedding took place at Kololo Mosque.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Mama-Fina-gets-married-again-given-Shs19m/688334-4095922-ecn1k7/index.html |title=Mama Fiina gets married again, given Shs19 million | accessdate=16 November 2017 |location=Kampala | first=Joseph |last=Kato |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]}}</ref> She has been married in the past, to the late Major Major Muhammad Kiggundu who was assassinated in November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|date=26 November 2016 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Gunmen--kill--Sheik--Maj-Kiggundu/688334-3465564-p75oe4/index.html |title=Police link Major Kiggundu's assassination to ADF rebels |accessdate=16 November 2017 |location=Kampala |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]| | author=Monitor Reporter}}</ref> She was previously married to Ali Kyonjo, who was her husband in 2014.<ref name="Beg"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1461646/maama-fina-walks-aisle-catch Maama Fina ties the knot again]

{{other people}} {{Infobox military person | name = Thomas Allin | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1757|05|14}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1833|06|26|1757|05|14}} | placeofburial_label = Resting place | birth_place = [[Hanover County, Virginia]] | death_place = [[Mercer County, Kentucky]] | placeofburial = Springhill Cemetery | nickname = | allegiance = [[Thirteen Colonies]], [[United States]] | branch = North Carolina militia, [[Continental Army]], Virginia militia | serviceyears = | rank = [[Major]] | unit = | commands = | battles = [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], [[Northwest Indian War]] | awards = | relations = | laterwork = [[Surveying|Surveyor]], [[clerk (position)|Clerk]] }}
'''Thomas Allin''' (May 14, 1757 – June 26, 1833) was a soldier and [[Surveying|surveyor]] who became an early settler and political leader in [[Kentucky]]. He served in the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], first in the North Carolina militia and then as part of [[General officer|general]] [[Nathanael Greene]]'s campaign.
Following the war, Allin settled in the Kentucky district of Virginia. He participated in the [[Northwest Indian War]], fighting with future [[Governor of Kentucky|Kentucky governor]] [[Charles Scott (governor of Kentucky)|Charles Scott]]. He then became the surveyor for the [[Transylvania Company]], laying out the towns of [[Harrodsburg, Kentucky|Harrodsburg]] and [[Henderson, Kentucky|Henderson]]. He served for many years as [[county clerk]] and [[Kentucky Circuit Courts|circuit court]] clerk in [[Mercer County, Kentucky]]. He was succeeded in these offices by two of his sons. He died of [[cholera]] on June 26, 1833.
==Early life and military career== Thomas Allin was born the son of William and Frances (Grant) Allin in [[Hanover County, Virginia]] on May 14, 1757. The following year, the family moved to [[Granville County, North Carolina]], where Allin was raised on the family farm.<ref name=holmberg16>Holmberg, p. 16</ref>
Allin enlisted as a [[Private (rank)|private]] in the North Carolina militia shortly after the beginning of the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]].<ref name=holmberg16 /><ref name=perrin>Perrin</ref> Later, he served in the army of [[General officer|general]] [[Nathaneal Greene]] and participated in the [[Battle of Guilford Courthouse]].<ref name=perrin />
Allin's first visit to Kentucky was in 1780.<ref name=holmberg16 /> In 1781, he moved to St. Asaph's (now [[Stanford, Kentucky|Stanford]]) in [[Lincoln County, Kentucky|Lincoln County]].<ref name=perrin /> He was chosen as deputy surveyor for Lincoln County, and in 1782, he became the county's [[deputy sheriff]].<ref name=holmberg16 /> He held both positions until approximately 1786.<ref name=holmberg16 /> He surveyed the land for the site of what is now [[Lexington, Kentucky]], and as compensation, received the land that [[Newport, Kentucky]] now occupies.<ref name=perrin /> He later lost this land in a lawsuit.<ref name=perrin />
As a [[Captain (United States)|captain]] in the [[Northwest Indian War]], Allin commanded a [[company (military)|company]] of mounted infantry under General [[Charles Scott (governor of Kentucky)|Charles Scott]] in [[Indiana]], and participated in the [[Battle of Tippecanoe]].<ref name=perrin /><ref name=currey382>Currey, p. 382</ref> Before the end of this enlistment, he was promoted to [[major]] and served as [[quartermaster]] and [[commissary]].<ref name=holmberg16 />
==Settlement in Kentucky== Following the war, Allin moved to [[Danville, Kentucky]], where he became a deputy clerk for the Supreme Court of the District of Kentucky, serving in the office of [[Christopher Greenup]].<ref name=holmberg16 /><ref name=perrin /> He held this post until 1792.<ref name=holmberg16 /> After the creation of [[Mercer County, Kentucky]] in 1786, he was chosen as the first [[county clerk]] and the clerk of the [[circuit court]].<ref name=perrin /> He represented [[Mercer County, Kentucky|Mercer County]] to the Virginia constitutional convention in June 1788.<ref name=holmberg17>Holmberg, p. 17</ref> He and ten other delegates from the Kentucky district voted against the new constitution; three Kentucky delegates voted for the new constitution, and one abstained.<ref name=holmberg17 />
On February 16, 1787, Allin married Mary Jouett of [[Albemarle County, Virginia]].<ref name=perrin /> Jouett was the aunt of noted painter [[Matthew Harris Jouett]].<ref>Currey, p. 585</ref> They had ten children.<ref name=perrin /> Both Allin and his wife were both members of the [[Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)|Christian Church]].<ref name=perrin />
Allin was invited to become a member of the [[Danville Political Club]] at the Club's second meeting, and served as its treasurer and secretary ''pro tempore''.<ref name=holmberg16 /><ref>Speed, p. 101</ref> He was also a charter member of the Kentucky Society for the Promotion of Useful Knowledge in 1787.<ref name=holmberg17 /> In August 1799, He represented Mercer County at Kentucky's second constitutional convention.<ref name=holmberg17 />
Allin was the surveyor for the [[Transylvania Company]], and laying out the site of the city of [[Henderson, Kentucky]] in 1797.<ref name=holmberg16 /> He also helped lay out the town of [[Harrodsburg, Kentucky]], and served as clerk of its board of trustees from March 24, 1786 to May 4, 1816.<ref name=holmberg16 /> In 1811, he was elected surveyor for the town of Danville.<ref name=holmberg16 /> In addition to surveying, he operated a farm, a mill, and a distillery.<ref name=holmberg16 />
Allin resigned as circuit court clerk in 1825 and as county clerk in 1831.<ref name=holmberg16 /> His son, Ben, succeeded him in the former office, and his son, Thomas, Jr., succeeded him in the latter.<ref name=johnson1144>Johnson, p. 1144</ref> He died of [[cholera]] on June 26, 1833 and was buried in Springhill Cemetery in Harrodsburg.<ref name=holmberg17 />

[[Covenant Theological Seminary]] ([[Master of Divinity|MDiv]]) |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{army|United States}} |serviceyears = 1972–1980 |unit = [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]]
[[United States Army Reserve|U.S. Army Reserve]] }} '''William Todd Akin''' (born July 5, 1947) is an American politician who is a former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|MO|2}}, serving from 2001 to 2013. He is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. Born in [[New York City]], Akin grew up in the [[Greater St. Louis]] area. After receiving his bachelor's degree from [[Worcester Polytechnic Institute]] in Massachusetts, Akin served in the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] and worked in the private sector in the computer and steel industries. In 1988, he was elected to the [[Missouri House of Representatives]]. He served in the state house until 2000, when he was elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]], in which he served until 2013. Akin's Congressional career ended after he lost a bid to unseat [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] U.S. Senator [[Claire McCaskill]] in the [[United States Senate election in Missouri, 2012|2012 election]]. Akin, who had won the Republican primary in a crowded field, led McCaskill in pre-election polls until [[Rape and pregnancy controversies in United States elections, 2012#Todd Akin|he said]] that women who are victims of what he called "legitimate rape" [[Pregnancy from rape|rarely get pregnant]]. Akin eventually apologized for the remark but rebuffed calls to withdraw from the election.{{Cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1112/83449.html |work=Politico |first=Jennifer |last=Haberkorn |title=Abortion, rape controversy shaped key races |date=November 6, 2012}} He lost to McCaskill by 54.7 percent to 39.2 percent. In a book published in July 2014, Akin said that he regretted apologizing and defended his original comments. ==Early life, education, and business career== Akin was born in [[New York City]], and raised in the [[St. Louis]] area. He is the son of Nancy Perry (née Bigelow) and Paul Bigelow Akin.[https://www.nytimes.com/1944/09/09/archives/troth-announced.html Announcements], The New York Times, September 9, 1944, Section Sports, Page 21.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/22/us/politics/todd-akins-faith-is-central-to-his-politics.html| title=A Politician Whose Faith Is Central to His Persistence|first=John|last=Eligon|date=August 21, 2012 |work=The New York Times}}{{cite book|title=The Penniman Family: To 1980|author1=Penniman, G.W.|author2=Bigelow, P.|author3=Penniman, G.D.|date=1987|publisher=Penniman Family|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpJJAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=2015-09-13}} Akin's great-grandfather, Thomas Russell Akin, founded [[Alton Steel|Laclede Steel Corporation]] of St. Louis in 1911.[https://www.nytimes.com/1966/03/26/archives/laclede-steel-names-chief.html Laclede Steel Names Chief], The New York Times, Business and Finance Section, March 26, 1966. The company eventually passed to his grandfather, William Akin, and then to his father Paul, a third-generation graduate of [[Harvard University]] who served as an officer in the Navy during World War II. Akin graduated from [[John Burroughs School]], a private [[University-preparatory school|prep school]] in suburban St. Louis, and went on to attend [[Worcester Polytechnic Institute]] in [[Worcester, Massachusetts]], earning a B.S. in Management Engineering in 1970. After graduation, Akin served as an engineer officer in the [[U.S. National Guard|National Guard]] of the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]],[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=%2Fstatepub&CISOPTR=99477&REC=17&CISOBOX=akin Official Manual of the State of Missouri, 1993–1994]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, p. 157 then served in the [[United States Army Reserve|Army Reserve]] until 1980.[http://akin.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9&Itemid=2 Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120824000846/http://akin.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9&Itemid=2 |date=2012-08-24 }}, Congressman Todd Akin, Missouri's 2nd District, retrieved 2012-08-23. After leaving active duty, Akin sold large computer systems for [[IBM]], then worked as a manager in his family's steel business. Akin earned a [[Master of Divinity]] degree in 1984 from [[Covenant Theological Seminary]] where he studied Greek, Hebrew, and a socially conservative interpretation of the Christian scriptures. He did not enter the ministry.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/akins-congressional-legacy-small-but-his-support-among-christian-groups-is-big/2012/08/22/b2c2d98e-ec75-11e1-aca7-272630dfd152_story_1.html|title=Akin's agenda wins loyalty of Christian groups|author1=McCrummen, Stephanie |author2=Fahrenthold, David A. |lastauthoramp=yes |work=Washington Post|date=August 22, 2012}} Akin is a longtime [[pro-life]] activist and former member of the board of Missouri Right to Life.Todd Akin Senate Campaign 2012 web site, On the Issues: Life, http://www.akin.org/issues/life, accessed 2012-11-04. He was arrested for trespass at least eight times between 1985 and 1988 while demonstrating against abortion in front of abortion clinics in Illinois and Missouri.{{cite news |url=http://hotlineoncall.nationaljournal.com/archives/2012/11/records-show-ak.php |title=Akin was Arrested at Least Eight Times in 1980s |first=Dan |last=Friedman |work=Hotline On Call |publisher=NationalJournal.com |date=November 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105005549/http://hotlineoncall.nationaljournal.com/archives/2012/11/records-show-ak.php |archivedate=2012-11-05 |df= }}{{cite news|last=McDermott|first=Kevin|title=Todd Akin was arrested at least three times during '80s abortion protests|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/political-fix/todd-akin-was-arrested-at-least-three-times-during-s/article_daebda70-1d5b-11e2-9adc-0019bb30f31a.html|accessdate=2012-10-24|newspaper=St. Louis Post Dispatch|date=October 24, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Kim|first=Seung Min|title=Akin speaks about old arrest at abortion clinic|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/on-congress/2012/09/akin-speaks-about-old-arrest-at-abortion-clinic-136954.html?hp=f1|work=Politico|date=September 28, 2012|accessdate=2012-11-03}} He has said the protests were peaceful and he would not apologize for standing up for his beliefs.{{cite news|title=2 top Mo. Republicans reverse course, come back to Akin’s side in contentious Senate race|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/mo-sen-mccaskill-defends-self-as-polite-and-calm-after-akin-says-she-was-not-as-ladylike/2012/09/28/ba031928-0978-11e2-9eea-333857f6a7bd_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003232022/http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/mo-sen-mccaskill-defends-self-as-polite-and-calm-after-akin-says-she-was-not-as-ladylike/2012/09/28/ba031928-0978-11e2-9eea-333857f6a7bd_story.html|archive-date=October 3, 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=September 28, 2012|deadurl=yes}} At the time of the arrests, he was using the name "William Akin"; after that period, when he ran for political office, it was as "Todd Akin". ==Missouri House of Representatives== ===Elections=== Akin was elected to the [[Missouri House of Representatives]] in November 1988, running unopposed to represent District 85 in West County.[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=%2Fstatepub&CISOPTR=92231&REC=10&CISOBOX=akin Official Manual of the State of Missouri 1989–1990]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, p. 669. He won re-election in 1990 with 59% of the vote.[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/statepub&CISOPTR=97970&REC=10 Official Manual of the State of Missouri 1991–1992]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, p. 506. Due to re-districting, Akin represented District 86 from 1993 through 2000, never winning less than 66% of the vote.[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=%2Fstatepub&CISOPTR=99477&REC=17&CISOBOX=akin Official Manual of the State of Missouri, 1993–1994]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, p. 716.[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/statepub&CISOPTR=95089&REC=5 Official Manual of the State of Missouri, 1995–1996]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, p. 541.[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/statepub&CISOPTR=93684&REC=4 Official Manual of the State of Missouri 1997–1998]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} p. 574.[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/statepub&CISOPTR=96610&REC=7 Official Manual of the State of Missouri 1999–2000]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} p. 571. ===Tenure=== Akin served as a member of the House Ways and Means Committee.{{cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB04F928C618B8F&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch | title=Tangled Politics Of Coming Election Apply Ice To Missouri's Tax-Cut Fever | date=1996-04-07}} During his 12 years in the state house, Akin advocated for [[Homeschooling|homeschool]] rights, voted for [[concealed carry permit|carrying concealed weapons]], voted against the parks and soils [[sales tax]], and voted against the 1993 tax increase and education spending increase.{{cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB04FF2A1063D61&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch | title=For The Missouri House – Iv | date=1996-11-01}} Akin sponsored legislation to prohibit [[Casino industry|casino companies]] from contributing to Missouri state lawmakers.{{cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB086CE430588D9&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch | title=Casinos Decry Proposal To Stop Contributions Similar Efforts Have Withstood Court Challenges | date=1998-03-17}} In 1995, he fought Democratic Governor [[Mel Carnahan]] over a bill providing state funding for school nurses. Ultimately, the governor refused to sign the funding bill due to Akin's amendment, which would have prohibited nurses from telling students about sources for information about abortion.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9zUjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a9gEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1361,2108434&dq=todd+akin&hl=en |accessdate=2012-01-29|title=Carnahan blasts 'extremists'|agency=The Associated Press|date=May 14, 1995|work=The Southeast Missourian}} ==U.S. House of Representatives== ===Elections=== In 2000, Akin ran in the Republican [[primary election]] to fill the House seat vacated by [[U.S. Representative]] [[Jim Talent]], who was running for governor. Light voter turnout caused by heavy rains helped Akin win the tight, five-way primary by just 56 votes; he defeated two better-known candidates, former St. Louis County Executive [[Gene McNary]] and [[Missouri Senate|State Senator]] [[Franc Flotron]].{{cite web|title=U.S. Representative – District 2 – Summary|url=http://www.sos.mo.gov/enrweb/raceresults.asp?eid=13&oid=3681&arc=1|publisher=Office of Secretary of State, Missouri|accessdate=2011-05-09}}{{cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/opinion/columns/kevin-horrigan/horrigan-the-world-discovers-the-weirdness-of-todd-akin-darn/article_f9135e2d-a7cc-508a-a544-cf8d5f3bf203.html|title=Horrigan: The world discovers the weirdness of Todd Akin. Darn it.|first=Kevin|last=Horrigan|date=August 21, 2012|work=St. Louis Today|publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch}} On the night he won the primary, Akin said, "My base will show up in earthquakes." He defeated Democratic State Senator Ted House in the general election, winning 55 percent of the vote.{{cite web|title=U.S. Representative – District 2 – Summary|url=http://www.sos.mo.gov/enrweb/raceresults.asp?eid=14&oid=3986&arc=1|publisher=Office of Secretary of State, Missouri|accessdate=2011-05-09}} He never faced another contest as close, and was reelected five times. In 2010, Akin won re-election with 67.9% of the vote.{{cite news | title = Missouri | work = Election 2010 | publisher =The New York Times | url = http://elections.nytimes.com/2010/results/missouri | doi = | accessdate = 2010-11-27}} He had been challenged for the seat by Democratic nominee Arthur Lieber, Libertarian nominee Steve Mosbacher, and write-in candidate Patrick M. Cannon. ===Tenure=== Akin earned a 96% rating from the [[American Conservative Union]] in 2008, and 100% in 2007.{{cite book |last=Barone |first=Michael |authorlink=Michael Barone (pundit) |author2=[[Richard E. Cohen]] |title=[[The Almanac of American Politics|The Almanac of American Politics 2010]] |year=2009 |page=875 |publisher=[[National Journal]] |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |isbn=978-0-89234-119-1}} For most of his tenure, Akin was listed in the official House roll as "R-St. Louis," even though his district didn't include any portion of the city of St. Louis.See, for example, the [http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/olm-112.pdf official House member list] during Akin's last term in the House. ====Social issues==== Akin is an outspoken opponent of [[abortion]] in all cases, including health reasons or in cases of [[rape]] or [[incest]], and he opposes [[embryonic stem cell research]]. In a 2008 speech on the House floor, Akin called abortion providers "terrorists" and alleged that it was "common practice" for abortion providers to perform "abortions" on women who were not actually pregnant.{{cite news | publisher = [[KMOX]] CBS | title = Akin In 2008: Doctors Give Abortions To Patients Who Aren't Pregnant | url = http://stlouis.cbslocal.com/2012/10/03/akin-in-2008-doctors-give-abortions-to-patients-who-arent-pregnant/ | date = October 3, 2012 | accessdate= 2012-10-03}}{{cite news | work = [[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] | title = Long before 'legitimate rape' comment, Akin alleged abortions on non-pregnant women | url = http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/long-before-legitimate-rape-comment-akin-alleged-abortions-on-non/article_f5f0c752-0d72-11e2-b591-0019bb30f31a.html | date = October 3, 2012 | accessdate = 2012-10-03 | first = Kevin | last = McDermott}} Akin is a supporter of the [[right to keep and bear arms]] and has an ''A'' rating from the [[National Rifle Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.akin.org/issues/2nd-amendment |title=2nd Amendment | Todd Akin for Senate |publisher=Akin.org |accessdate=2012-08-24}} Akin has stated that he has supported many bills including the Second Amendment Sovereignty Act of 2012, The Sportsmen's Heritage Act and the Disaster Recovery Personal Protection Act.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} Akin is a staunch advocate of a federal prohibition of [[online poker]]. In 2006, he co-sponsored H.R. 4411, the [[Goodlatte]]-[[Jim Leach|Leach]] Internet Gambling Prohibition Act,{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:h.r.04411: |title=Thomas (Library of Congress): HR 4411 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |accessdate=2011-05-09}} and H.R. 4777, the Internet Gambling Prohibition Act.{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:h.r.04777: |title=Thomas (Library of Congress): HR 4777 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |accessdate=2011-05-09}} Akin also authored the Protect the Pledge (of Allegiance) Act. In late June 2011, Akin objected to [[NBC television|NBC's]] recent removal of the words "under God" from a video clip of school children reciting the [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]]. After remarking that "NBC has a long record of being very liberal," Akin said, "at the heart of liberalism really is a hatred for God and a belief that government should replace God".{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/06/28/lawmaker-apologizes-for-liberal-hatred-god-quip/ |publisher=Fox News |title=Lawmaker Apologizes for Liberal 'Hatred of God' Quip |author=Colby Hochmuth |date=June 28, 2011|accessdate=2011-08-27}} Two days later, Akin said he did not mean all liberals hate God, only that liberals have "a hatred for public references for God." The next day, he apologized, saying his statement had been "directed at the political movement, Liberalism, not at any specific individual".{{cite web |url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/article_257a8021-15ab-5006-9245-cca7ad534d62.html |title=Akin changes course, apologizes for comment|publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |author=Jason Hancock |date=June 29, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-27}} During his 2012 US Senate bid, Akin reaffirmed his opposition to legislation like the [[Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009]], which he voted against as a Congressman.{{cite news | work = [[Washington Post]] | title = Todd Akin on women's issues in Kansas City campaign stop | first = Diana | last = Reese | date = October 1, 2012 | accessdate = 2012-10-03 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/she-the-people/wp/2012/10/01/todd-akin-on-womens-issues-in-kansas-city-campaign-stop/}} Todd Akin is an opponent of the [[No Child Left Behind Act]]. Akin believes that it should not be the federal government that decides on education, but that local government should have control over public education.{{cite web|url=http://www.akin.org/issues/life |title=2nd Amendment | Todd Akin for Senate |publisher=Akin.org |accessdate=2012-11-21}} On MSNBC, Todd Akin opposes [[evolution]]. He was running for the senate seat in Missouri at the time. He has said "I take a look at both sides of the thing and it seems to me that evolution takes a tremendous amount of faith. I don't even see it as a matter of science because I don't know if you can prove....".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=51mi7dDbitk NEWSROOMMSNBC], Youtube, NEWSROOMMSNBC ====Fiscal issues==== In his early years in Congress, Akin brought back [[earmark (politics)|earmarks]] for his district, voted to raise the debt ceiling, voted for off-balance-sheet wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and voted to create the unfunded Medicare prescription drug benefit. More recently, he has opposed increases in taxation and spending. He voted in 2007 against an expansion of the [[State Children's Health Insurance Program]] (SCHIP), objecting to its potential coverage of children in families making up to $62,000 a year, and stating that proof of U.S. citizenship was not required. He also said the bill would "weaken the private health care system" and lead the country "further down the slippery slope to socialized medicine."{{cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/political-fix/mo-dems-gop-split-over-schip-while-protesters-target-bond/article_8b32e603-2acc-5fa2-a752-8aad7fbd0780.html|title=Mo Dems- GOP split over SCHIP, while protesters target Bond, who backs SCHIP|first=Jo|last=Mannies|date=October 4, 2007|work=St Louis Today}} He has voted against federally funded school breakfasts and lunches, and called student loans "a stage-three cancer of socialism". He has also voted against increasing the minimum wage. He was a vocal critic of the September 2008 bank bailout, and voted against it.{{cite news|url=|title=Bailout critic Akin also target of spray-paint vandals |first=Jo|last=Mannies|work=St Louis Today}} He voted no on the Affordable Health Care Act in March 2010,{{cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/opinion/columns/the-platform/charting-the-votes-the-money-and-the-uninsured/article_0e70aaf5-0216-5dc8-b64e-f9495a0d50b5.html|title=Charting the votes, the money and the uninsured|work=St Louis Post-Dispatch|date=March 24, 2010}} and on Paul Ryan's fiscal year 2012 budget.{{cite web|url=http://akin.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1629 |title=Akin Supports Ryan Budget |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921175558/http://akin.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1629 |archivedate=2012-09-21 |df= }} ====Military issues==== Akin has spent time working on military and veterans issues. On the [[House Armed Services Committee]] he served as the Chairman of the Seapower and Projection Forces Subcommittee, which handles Navy and Air Force issues. He has served as Ranking Republican on the Seapower Subcommittee and the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee. Akin has also introduced veterans-related bills, most notably the Open Burn Pit Registry Act, which creates a registry for [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] veterans who were exposed to [[burn pits]]. He opposed repeal of the Dover Policy, which banned media coverage of caskets of troops returning home from overseas, citing privacy and decorum issues. ===Committee assignments=== * '''[[United 2012 |df= }} The Claire McCaskill campaign spent $2 million during the primaries, despite not having a primary opponent. That money was spent on advertising touting Akin as "Too conservative," for Missouri.{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2012/0821/Why-Claire-McCaskill-wants-Todd-Akin-to-stay-in-Missouri-race |title=Why Claire McCaskill wants Todd Akin to stay in Missouri race |publisher=CS Monitor |date=August 21, 2012 |accessdate=2012-12-13}} In 2012, ''[[National Journal]]'' named Akin one of ten [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] to follow on [[Twitter]].[https://news.yahoo.com/ten-republicans-twitter-221744599.html "Ten Republicans to follow on Twitter," by Adam Mazmanian, ''National Journal'', August 27, 2012], Retrieved November 20, 2015. Akin faced McCaskill and Libertarian nominee [[United States Senate election in Missouri, 2012#Libertarian primary|Jonathan Dine]] in the general election, losing to McCaskill after [[#Controversial comments on rape and pregnancy|his controversial comments on rape]] lost him a great deal of support. ===Home of record=== In May 2011, questions were raised about Akin's official address for voting. For most of his political career, Akin had claimed [[Town and Country, Missouri|Town and Country]] as his official residence. However, according to the [[Associated Press]] and the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'', Akin moved to [[Wildwood, Missouri|Wildwood]], in far western St. Louis County, sometime between 2007 and 2009, after he and his wife purchased a second home there. However, he continued to vote as a Town and Country resident, and signed a polling place logbook attesting to his living there in April 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/article_a4e87e23-6e54-5f0c-a5fe-28367ef2ba75.html|title=Todd Akin votes in Town and Country|publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch website|date= 2011-05-31|accessdate=2011-06-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kmov.com/news/local/Missouri-Rep-Akin-voting-living-at-different-places-122872884.html |title=Missouri Rep. Akin voting, living at different places. |publisher=Associated Press via KMOV-TV |date=2011-05-31 |accessdate=2011-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314060633/http://www.kmov.com/news/local/Missouri-Rep-Akin-voting-living-at-different-places-122872884.html |archivedate=2012-03-14 |df= }} ==={{visible anchor|Controversial comments on "legitimate rape" and pregnancy|Controversial_comments_on_rape_and_pregnancy}}=== {{Main|Rape and pregnancy controversies in United States elections, 2012}} {{See also|Pregnancy from rape}} In a local news interview, on August 19, 2012, discussing [[abortion]], Akin claimed that victims of what he described as "legitimate rape" very rarely become [[pregnancy|pregnant]]. Airing on St. Louis television station [[KTVI]], his response to a question on [[rape]] exceptions for [[abortion]] was:
Well you know, people always want to try to make that as one of those things, well how do you, how do you slice this particularly tough sort of ethical question. First of all, from what I understand from doctors, that's really rare. If it's a legitimate rape, the female body has ways to try to shut that whole thing down. But let's assume that maybe that didn't work or something. I think there should be some punishment, but the punishment ought to be on the rapist and not attacking the child.{{cite web|last=Jaco|first=Charles|title=The Jaco Report: August 19, 2012|url=http://fox2now.com/2012/08/19/the-jaco-report-august-19-2012/|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=2012-08-20}}
The comments from Akin, which came as he ran for the [[U.S. Senate]] seat held by [[Claire McCaskill]], almost immediately led to widespread uproar. The term "legitimate rape" was called "loathsome" because it suggests that "there are different categories of rape — some real and awful and others that are not".{{cite news |author= The Washington Post Editorial Board |title=The repugnant code behind Todd Akin’s words | date=20 Aug 2012 | URL=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-repugnant-code-behind-todd-akins-words/2012/08/20/7e91ed12-eb08-11e1-a80b-9f898562d010_story.html |accessdate=9 Oct 2016}} Others took exception to the phrasing because it suggests that the victims who do become [[Pregnancy from rape|pregnant from rape]] may be [[False accusation of rape|lying]]. His claims about the likelihood of pregnancy resulting from rape were seen by some as being based on fringe ideas like stress-induced [[miscarriage]] or Dr. [[John C. Willke]]'s "spastic tubes" theory introduced in 1985{{cite news | title = Health Experts Dismiss Assertions on Rape | date = 2012-08-21 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/21/us/politics/rape-assertions-are-dismissed-by-health-experts.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2012-08-21 | first=Pam | last=Belluck}} and trauma-based theory introduced in 1999.[http://www.christianliferesources.com/article/rape-pregnancies-are-rare-461 Rape Pregnancies Are Rare] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419181455/http://www.christianliferesources.com/article/rape-pregnancies-are-rare-461 |date=2013-04-19 }} by [[John Willke]]. ''christianliferesources.com''. These theories are not accepted by the majority of the scientific and medical community.{{cite news | title = A Canard That Will Not Die: 'Legitimate Rape' Doesn't Cause Pregnancy | date = 19 August 2012 | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/08/a-canard-that-will-not-die-legitimate-rape-doesnt-cause-pregnancy/261303/ | work = The Atlantic | accessdate = 2012-08-21}}{{cite web|first=David A. |last=Graham |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/08/video-of-the-day-forcible-rape-and-paul-ryans-akin-problem/261460 |title=Video of the Day: 'Forcible Rape' and Paul Ryan's Akin Problem |publisher=The Atlantic |date=August 22, 2012 |accessdate=2012-08-25}} Akin was not the first to make such claims, but was perhaps one of the most recently prominent.{{cite news|last=Kliff |first=Sarah |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/wp/2012/08/20/rep-todd-akin-is-wrong-about-rape-and-pregnancy-but-hes-not-alone/ |title=Rep. Todd Akin is wrong about rape and pregnancy, but he's not alone |publisher=The Washington Post |date=August 20, 2012 |accessdate=2012-08-22}} The comment was widely characterized as [[misogyny|misogynistic]] and recklessly inaccurate, with many commentators remarking on the use of the words "legitimate rape".{{cite news|last=DiSalvo|first=David|title=Republican Senate Nominee Todd Akin: Victims Of "Legitimate Rape" Don't Get Pregnant|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/daviddisalvo/2012/08/19/republican-senate-nominee-todd-akin-victims-of-legitimate-rape-dont-get-pregnant/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=2012-08-20}}{{cite web|last=Abouhalkah|first=Yael T.|title=Todd Akin's rape fantasy|url=http://voices.kansascity.com/entries/todd-akins-rape-fantasy/|publisher=Kansas City Star|accessdate=2012-08-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.li/20130901221142/http://voices.kansascity.com/entries/todd-akins-rape-fantasy/|archivedate=2013-09-01|df=}}{{cite news|last=Eligon|first=John|title=Senate Candidate Provokes Ire With 'Legitimate Rape' Comment|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/20/us/politics/todd-akin-provokes-ire-with-legitimate-rape-comment.html|accessdate=2012-08-20|work=The New York Times|date=August 19, 2012}} Related news articles cited a 1996 article in an obstetrics and gynecology journal, which found that 5% of women who were raped became pregnant, which equaled about 32,000 pregnancies each year in the US alone.{{cite journal |first1=Melisa M. |last1=Holmes |first2=Heidi S. |last2=Resnick |first3=Dean G. |last3=Kilpatrick |first4=Connie L. |last4=Best |title=Rape-related pregnancy: Estimates and descriptive characteristics from a national sample of women |journal=American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology |pmid=8765248 |year=1996 |volume=175 |issue=2 |pages=320–4; discussion 324–5 |doi=10.1016/S0002-9378(96)70141-2}} Cited in: {{cite news |last=Blake |first=Aaron |title=Todd Akin, GOP Senate candidate: 'Legitimate rape' rarely causes pregnancy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2012/08/19/todd-akin-gop-senate-candidate-legitimate-rape-rarely-causes-pregnancy/ |publisher=Washington Post |accessdate=2012-08-20}} A separate 2003 article in the journal ''[[Human Nature (journal)|Human Nature]]'' estimated that rapes are twice as likely to result in pregnancies as consensual sex.{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s12110-003-1014-0 |title=Are per-incident rape-pregnancy rates higher than per-incident consensual pregnancy rates? |year=2003 |last1=Gottschall |first1=Jonathan A. |last2=Gottschall |first2=Tiffani A. |journal=Human Nature |volume=14 |pages=1–20}} Cited in: {{cite web |last=Robillard |first=Kevin |title=Doctors: Todd Akin pregnancy claim bogus |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0812/79895.html |publisher=Politico |accessdate=2012-08-21}} While some colleagues such as Iowa congressman [[Steve King]]{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-57497428-503544/rep-steve-king-backs-up-todd-akin-weighs-in-on-rape-and-abortion/ |title=Rep. Steve King backs up Todd Akin, weighs in on rape and abortion |work=CBS News |accessdate=2012-08-29}} and Tennessee state senator [[Stacey Campfield]]{{cite web|title=Sen. Campfield Continues to Embarrass Tennessee|url=http://www.tennesseean.com/sen-stacey-campfield-tennessee/|publisher=Tennesseean|accessdate=2014-03-19}} supported Akin, senior figures in both parties condemned his remarks and some Republicans called for him to resign.{{cite news |url= http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/08/20/leading-social-conservatives-rally-to-akins-defense/ |title=Leading social conservatives rally to Akin's defense|work=[[CNN]] |date=2012-08-20 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=2012-08-21}}{{cite web|author=Seung Min Kim |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/on-congress/2012/08/list-of-senators-calling-on-akin-to-quit-keeps-growing-132703.html |title=List of senators calling on Akin to quit keeps growing |publisher=Politico |date=August 21, 2012 |accessdate=2012-08-22}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/314452/romney-akins-inexcusable-comment-robert-costa|title=Romney: Akin's Comment 'Inexcusable'|last=Costa|first=Robert}} In the resulting furor, Akin received widespread calls to drop out of his Senate race from both Republicans and Democrats.{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/08/20/gop-chair-akin-should-drop-out-skip-convention/|title=GOP chair: Akin should drop out, skip convention|last=Killough|first=Ashley|date=August 20, 2012|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=2012-08-21}} Akin apologized for his [[political gaffe|gaffe]], saying he "misspoke." His campaign ran an advertisement in which he asked voters to forgive him, saying:
Rape is an evil act. I used the wrong words in the wrong way and for that I apologize. As the father of two daughters, I want tough justice for predators. I have a compassionate heart for the victims of sexual assault. I pray for them. The fact is, rape can lead to pregnancy. The truth is, rape has many victims. The mistake I made was in the words I said, not in the heart I hold. I ask for your forgiveness.{{cite web|last=Burns|first=Alexander|title=Akin ad asks for 'forgiveness' |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/burns-haberman/2012/08/exclusive-akin-ad-asks-for-forgiveness-132648.html|publisher=Politico|accessdate=2013-11-07}}
The incident was seen as having an impact on Akin's senate race and the Republicans' chances of gaining a majority in the U.S. Senate,[http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/politics/Todd-Akin-Legitimate-Rape-Election-166766356.html Akin Vows to Stay in Race After "Legitimate Rape" Gaffe] NBC 10 Philadelphia Scott Ross Monday, Aug 20, 2012 | Updated 6:56 PM EDT by making news in the week before the [[2012 Republican National Convention]] and by "shift[ing] the national discussion to divisive social issues that could repel swing voters rather than economic issues that could attract them".[http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/22/politics/gop-akin-controversy/index.html Akin imbroglio is bad news for Republicans] Tom Cohen, CNN updated 3:23 PM EDT, Wed August 22, 2012 ===Election result=== Before the comments, Akin had been favored to win his race against McCaskill, but he lost in November, 54.7 percent to 39.2 percent.{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1112/83443.html |title=Missouri Senate election results 2012: Claire McCaskill beats Todd Akin for second term |publisher=politico.com|accessdate=2015-09-13}} His loss was attributed to backlash from women voters. After the election, between November 2012 and August 2013, Akin received $111,000 in donations that in part were for the 2018 Senate primaries.{{Citation |author=Kevin McDermott |publication-date=August 20, 2013 |title=A year after 'legitimate rape,' the money's still trickling in for Akin |work= [[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] |page= |url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/kevin-mcdermott/a-year-after-legitimate-rape-the-money-s-still-trickling/article_c7982f7b-0ab0-5967-959a-70e67d1b9318.html |accessdate=2013-12-28}} ===Aftermath=== In July 2014, Akin's book, ''Firing Back: Taking on the Party Bosses and Media Elite to Protect Our Faith and Freedom'', was published by [[WND Books]]. In it, he said that he regretted apologizing, because "by asking the public at large for forgiveness, I was validating the willful misinterpretation of what I had said." He also defended his original comments and attacked various Republicans for "wronging" him, including [[Karl Rove]]; former [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] Executive Director Rob Jesmer; Senators [[Mitch McConnell]], [[John Cornyn]], [[John McCain]], [[Roy Blunt]] and [[Lindsey Graham]]; and House Speaker [[John Boehner]]. He also repeatedly attacked the Republican establishment for seeing his comments "as their opportunity to take [me] out and select someone more palatable to their tastes", and the "[[Media bias in the United States#Liberal bias|liberal media]]" for making him "the target of a media assassination."{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/07/todd-akin-new-book-108745.html#ixzz3CIr617iC |title=Todd Akin returns to national stage |publisher=Politico |date=July 10, 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-04}} ==Personal life== Akin married Lulli Boe, a graduate of [[Hollins University]], in June 1975.[http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=%2Fstatepub&CISOPTR=92231&REC=10&CISOBOX=akin Official Manual of the State of Missouri 1989–1990]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, p. 135.[http://www.hollins.edu/alumnae/reunion/40thattendees.shtml Class of 1972 Reunion Attendees] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905002611/http://www.hollins.edu/alumnae/reunion/40thattendees.shtml |date=2012-09-05 }}, Hollins Alumnae page, Hollins University. The couple has six children. Lulli became a home schooling activist, and all of the children were home-schooled. Three sons attended the Naval Academy and became officers in the Marines. One of his sons served in the assault on [[Fallujah]], Iraq.{{cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/political-fix/mccaskill-skelton-support-dover-repeal-akin-unhappy/article_e75931a5-fd7f-5a14-9110-3111ea51fa6c.html|title=McCaskill, Skelton support Dover repeal; Akin unhappy|first=Sean|last=Rose|work= St Louis Today|date=February 26, 2009}} Akin enjoys playing guitar and singing gospel songs, and over the years, has dressed in Revolutionary War attire for Fourth of July celebrations. Akin and his wife lived for many years in his childhood home, a house owned by his father in affluent [[Town and Country, Missouri]]. When his father sought to subdivide the 8.5-acre property in the late 2000s, Akin moved to a house in Wildwood.{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/political-fix/todd-akin-s-deep-beliefs-and-loyal-base-are-hurdle/article_c41d61a4-eb4e-11e1-ad3e-0019bb30f31a.html |title=Akin in Ohio as {{other people||Thomas Dowd (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = | image = Tom_Dowd_demonstrating_the_mix_of_'Layla'.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Dowd demonstrates how he mixed "[[Layla]]" | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1925|10|20}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan, New York]] | origin = | death_date = {{death date and age|2002|10|27|1925|10|20}} | death_place = [[Aventura, Florida]] | genre = | occupation = [[Audio engineer]], [[record producer]] | instrument = | years_active = 1947–2002 | label = [[Atlantic Records]], [[Apex Studios]], [[Criteria Studios]] | associated_acts = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Thomas John "Tom" Dowd''' (October 20, 1925 – October 27, 2002) was an [[United States|American]] [[recording engineer]] and [[record producer|producer]] for [[Atlantic Records]]. He was credited with innovating the [[multitrack recording]] method. Dowd worked on a veritable "who's who" of recordings that encompassed blues, jazz, pop, rock and soul records.
==Career==
=== Early years === Born in [[Manhattan]], Dowd grew up playing piano, tuba, violin, and string bass. His mother was an opera singer and his father was a [[concertmaster]].
Dowd graduated from [[Stuyvesant High School]] in June 1942 at the age of 16.<ref name="SoS">{{cite journal |url=http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/Oct04/articles/rocketscience.htm |title=The Engineers Who Changed Recording |date=October 2004 |journal=Sound on Sound |last=Daley |first=Dan |accessdate=2007-11-01}}</ref> He continued his musical education at [[City College of New York]]. Dowd also played in a band at New York's [[Columbia University]], where he became a [[conducting|conductor]]. He was also employed at the [[physics]] laboratory of Columbia University.
=== Military work === At age 18, Dowd was [[Conscription in the United States|drafted]] into the military with the rank of [[sergeant]]. He continued his work in physics at Columbia University. He worked on the [[Manhattan Project]], which developed the [[atomic bomb]]. The purpose of the work was unclear until 1945.<ref name="languageofmusic">{{cite web |url=http://www.thelanguageofmusic.com/bio_40.HTM |title=Biography |publisher=''Tom Dowd and the Language of Music'' |accessdate=2007-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928212802/http://www.thelanguageofmusic.com/bio_40.HTM |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}</ref> Dowd planned to obtain a degree in [[nuclear physics]] when he completed his work on the Manhattan Project. However, because his work was top secret, the university did not recognize it, and Dowd decided not to continue, since the university's curriculum would not have been able to further his physics education. His research for the military was more advanced than academic courses at that time.<ref name="languageofmusic"/>
=== Music === Dowd took a job at a [[European classical music|classical music]] recording studio until he obtained employment at [[Atlantic Records]]. His first hit was [[Eileen Barton]]'s "[[If I Knew You Were Comin' I'd've Baked a Cake]]". He soon became a top [[audio engineering|recording engineer]] there and recorded popular artists such as [[Ray Charles]], [[the Drifters]], [[the Coasters]], [[The Spinners (American R&B group)|The Spinners]], [[Ruth Brown]] and [[Bobby Darin]], including Darin's famous rendition of [[Kurt Weill]]/[[Bertolt Brecht]]'s "Mack the Knife". He captured jazz masterpieces by [[John Coltrane]], [[Ornette Coleman]], [[Thelonious Monk]] and [[Charlie Parker]]. It was Dowd's idea to cut Ray Charles' recording of "[[What'd I Say]]" into two parts and release them as the A-side and B-side of the same single record.
Dowd worked as an engineer and producer from the 1940s until the beginning of the 21st century. While working for Atlantic Records, he lived in Westwood, NJ with his wife Jackie and his sons, Steven and Theodore. He recorded albums by many artists including [[Bee Gees]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]], [[Black Oak Arkansas]], [[Derek and the Dominos]], [[Rod Stewart]], [[Wishbone Ash]], [[New Model Army (band)|New Model Army]], [[Cream (band)|Cream]], [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]], [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]], [[the Allman Brothers Band]], [[Joe Bonamassa]], [[the J. Geils Band]], [[Meat Loaf]], [[Sonny & Cher]], [[the Rascals]], [[The Spinners (American R&B group)|The Spinners]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Diana Ross]], [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]], [[The Four Seasons (band)|the Four Seasons]], [[Kenny Loggins]], [[James Gang]], [[Dusty Springfield]], [[Eddie Harris]], [[Charles Mingus]], [[Herbie Mann]], [[Booker T. & the M.G.'s]], [[Otis Redding]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Joe Castro]] and [[Primal Scream]].<ref>{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p72005|pure_url=yes}} |publisher=Allmusic |title=Tom Dowd - Credits |accessdate=2007-11-01}}</ref> He was also an employee of [[Apex Studios]] in the 1950s.<ref name="Inc.2002">{{cite book|title=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OQ0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA6|accessdate=December 20, 2012|date=November 9, 2002|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|page=6|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> Dowd received a [[Grammy Trustees Award]] for his lifetime achievements in February 2002.
He died of [[emphysema]] on October 27, 2002, in [[Florida]], where he had been living and working at [[Criteria Studios]] for many years, a week after his 77th birthday.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/2003-01-16/film/soundman-god/|title=Soundman God|last=Norman|first=Forrest|date=January 16, 2003|work=New Times|accessdate=January 7, 2011|location=Miami}}</ref>
==Legacy== Tom Dowd helped to shape the artists that he worked with, and because he worked with an array of great artists on some of the world's greatest recordings, Dowd was highly influential in creating the sound of the second half of the 20th Century. It was he who encouraged [[Jerry Wexler]] of [[Atlantic Records]] to install an [[Ampex]] '''eight-track recorder''', enabling Atlantic to be the first recording company to record using multiple tracks.<ref>{{cite book | first=Matt | last= Dobkin | year= 2004 | title= I Never Loved a Man the Way I Loved You: Aretha Franklin, Respect, and the Making of a Soul Music Masterpiece | edition= | publisher= St. Martin's Press | location=New York | pages= 142–143 | isbn=0-312-31828-6 }}</ref>
Dowd is credited as the engineer who popularized the eight-track recording system for commercial music and popularized the use of [[stereophonic sound]]. He also pioneered the use of linear channel faders as opposed to rotary controls on audio mixers. He devised various methods for altering sound after the initial recording.<ref name="SoS"/>
In 2003 director Mark Moormann premiered an award-winning documentary about his life entitled ''[[Tom Dowd and the Language of Music]]''. In the 2004 biopic ''[[Ray (film)|Ray]]'', Tom Dowd was portrayed by actor [[Rick Gomez]].
Tom Dowd was posthumously inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 2012. The ceremony took place on April 14, 2012, and [[Robbie Robertson]] gave the induction speech.
